Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: Stopping...?

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: Man. They look woebegone and far away.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I'll only be here twenty-four hours.

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: In a place like this, it could be a lifetime.  Good luck, Mr. Macreedy.

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: You for Black Rock?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: There must be some mistake. I'm Hastings, the telegraph agent. Nobody told me the train was stopping.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: They didn't?

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: I just said they didn't, and they ought to. What I -- want to know, why didn't they?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Probably didn't think it was important.

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: Important?! It's the first time the streamliner stopped here in four years.  You being met? You visiting folks or something? I mean, whatd'ya want?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I want to go to Adobe Flat. Any cabs available?

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: No cabs.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Where's the hotel?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I asked where's the hotel?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: Hello, Pete? Now, listen...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: 'Afternoon.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: Anything I can do for you?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: You run this hotel?

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Then there's nothing you can do for me.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: Find Smith!

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I'd like a room.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: All filled up.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Got any idea where I might --

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: This is 1945, mister. There's been a war on.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I thought it ended a couple of months ago.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Yeah, but the O.P.A. lingers on.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: You don't know about the O.P.A...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Tell me.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Well, for establishments with less'n fifty rooms hotel keepers got to report regularly about...

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: ...about tenants and... and... registration...  There are penalties imposed...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: You seem to have lots of vacancies.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Well... as I said...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Lots of vacancies.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: They're everyone of 'em locked up. Some are show rooms...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Yes...?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: You understand...?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Not really. But while I'm pondering it, get a room ready. Just for tonight.  This one.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Sure could use a bath. Where is it?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Head of the stairs.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I don't know just why you're interested -- but the name's Macreedy. I'm...  It's all in the ledger.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: You look like you need a hand.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: I wanna know everything he does, Pete. Check every call -- any mail.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: And in the meantime...?

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: ...see if he's got any iron in his blood...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I think you have the wrong room.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: You think so?

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: What else you got on your mind?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Nothing, I guess.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: If you had a mind, boy, you'd of heard what Pete downstairs said. He said these here rooms are for us cowboys. For our every wish and comfort.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: And this, I guess, is yours?

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: When I'm in town. And I'm in town, as any fool can see. You see that, don't you, boy?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I guess I do. Would you mind very much if I sort of...  ...clean up this mess and get another room?

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: Not at all. But if you want this room real bad...  If a man don't claim what's rightfully his'n, he's nuthin'. What do you think?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I guess so.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: You guess so. But still you ain't claimin' this room?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I guess not.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: You're all the time guessin', boy. Don't you ever know anything?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: One thing I know. Since I got off the train, I've been needled. Why?

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: I guess I don't rightly know.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What do you think, Doc?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Why ask me? He's no salesman, that's sure.  Unless he's peddling dynamite.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Maybe he's a cop, or something...

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Ever see a cop with a stiff arm?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Maybe his arm's all right. Maybe he's just holding tight to something in his pocket...

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Why are you so interested, Sam?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Who, me?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I mean, if I was that interested...  ...I'd ask him.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Hey! Hold it!

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Got any cigarettes?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: This is all.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: How long you staying?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: In my new room, you mean?  I'm staying.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: I mean, in the hotel.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Just about twenty-four hours.  Why?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: I... I was just askin'.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Why? You expecting a convention?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: I was just askin'.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Stale.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Where can I rent a car?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Let's put it this way -- if I had a car and if I wanted to put gas in it, where would I go?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: But you don't have a car.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: You might try the garage at the end of the street.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Here we go again.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: That's all I know about him, Mr. Smith.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Sit down.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: I was only...

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Sit down.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: Pretty cool guy.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Doesn't push easy?

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: That's it -- that's just it. He pushes too easy. Maybe we oughtta...

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: What do you want, Doc?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Nothing.  Not that I have the slightest idea.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You wonder too much, and you talk too much.  It's a bad parlay, Doc.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I hold no truck with silence.  I got nothing to hide.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: What're you tryin' to say?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Nothing, man. It's just, you worry about the stranger only if you look at him...  ...from a certain aspect.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: How do you look at him, Doc?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: With the innocence of a fresh-laid egg.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: And some day I'll have Coley wash out your mouth with lye.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Hi, T.J.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: This your garage?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Where's the man it belongs to?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Where'd she go?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: When will she be back?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: I called the Circle T. He ain't got business there -- not if they don't know him. Right, Mr. Smith?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Send a wire to Nick Gandi in Los Angeles. Tell him to find out all he can about John J. Macreedy. Tell him I want to know fast. Sign my name.

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: What was that?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Nick Gandi. G-A-N-D-I. Care of the Blake Hotel.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: Who's Gandi?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: He's a private detective.  I drive to L.A. now and then.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: He'll get us the dope?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: He'll get us anything, for twenty bucks a day and expenses.  Hector, you worry too fast and too easy.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: It's just, I don't like it.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: Maybe he's just passing through.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: Don't bet on it. He can only mean trouble.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Hector, you're jumpy as a stall horse.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: We oughtta see him... talk to him.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You tried -- where'd it get you?

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: I only thought...

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Sure. You only thought.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: What do we do?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: What do you do? You wait. Like Pete here. Right, Pete?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: That's all you do. But while you wait... I talk to him.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Hey!

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Now what do you know?  Now what do you suppose he'd want to see the Sheriff about?

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Hold it, friend.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: I ain't hankerin' to get locked in my own jail.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Sorry. I thought you were a guest.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: As it happens, I'm the host.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Snort?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: No, thanks.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Don't blame you. It's awful.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: What're you lookin' at?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: You tell me.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: I ain't always this bad -- just that last night me and my pal Doc Velie, we did a little celebratin'. At least I did.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: What were you celebrating?

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: My name's Macreedy. I came in on the Streamliner.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: You what?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I said I came in...

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: You ain't from around here. Up Tucson way -- Phoenix? Mesa? You ain't sellin' cattle nor seed nor nothin' like that?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: No.  All I want from you is a little information. I've got to get to a place called Adobe Flat.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: This ain't no information bureau.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: One thing about Black Rock -- everybody's polite. Makes for gracious living.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Nobody asked you here.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: How do you know?

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: What about Adobe Flat?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I'm looking for a man named Komako.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Almost a disaster.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: You move fast for a crip... for a big man.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: What about Komako?

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: If there's no further questions...

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Mr. Macreedy.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: That's the friendliest word I've heard since I got here.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I want to apologize for some of the folks in town.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: They act like they're sitting on a keg.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: A keg...? Of what?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I don't know. Maybe diamonds. Maybe gunpowder.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: No. Nothing like that. We're a little suspicious of strangers is all. Hangover from the old days. The old West.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I thought the tradition of the old West was hospitality.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Going to be around for a while?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Could be.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: How would you like to go hunting tomorrow? I'd be proud to have you as my guest.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Thanks, but I'm afraid not.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I... What I mean is -- if there's anything I can do while you're around...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I'm looking for...  Never mind. Thanks, anyway.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You're looking for what, Mr. Macreedy?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: A man named Komako.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Komako -- Sure, I remember him -- Japanese farmer. Never had a chance.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: No?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: He got here in '41 -- just before Pearl Harbor. Three months later he was shipped to one of those relocation centers.  Tough.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Which one did he go to?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Who knows?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: You think maybe if I wrote him, the letter would be forwarded?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I'm sure it would. Write your letter. I'll see it gets out tonight.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: It wouldn't be too much trouble?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: No trouble at all.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Funny. Because I think it would be a great deal of trouble for you. It's been a great deal of trouble for me.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I wrote these letters to Komako. They weren't forwarded. They were returned -- address unknown.  So I guess there's nothing you can do for me, after all.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Need a little help?

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: I can manage.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Well, I need a little help.  I'd like to rent your jeep.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: It'll be two dollars an hour, gas extra, and ten dollars for my time.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Aren't you going to ask him where he wants to go?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: He wants to go to Adobe Flat.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: The road's marked?

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Yeah. It's about six -- seven miles down...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Then I won't need your time.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: I thought you might... need a little help.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I can manage.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Liz. Do you have a license to rent cars? You could get into trouble.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: It's all right. I won't mention it to the Sheriff.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You shouldn't have done that.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: I thought it would be better if he went out there and got done with it.  I mean, what could he find out?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: This is liable to be the hardest ten dollars you ever earned in your life.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: What did he want -- the stranger?

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: You think he'll kick up a storm?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: A storm? About what?

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: I don't know. All I know, I don't want trouble around here.  Never again.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Trouble? You don't know anything about Komako, now do you, Tim?

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: I do not. That's the point.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: The point is, what you don't know can't hurt you.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Maybe there's something I ought to know. Maybe I ought to ask you... before the stranger comes back and starts breathing down my neck.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Tim, you're a lost ball in the high weeds. I told you a long time ago, nothing happened for you to worry about.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: And I'm still the law.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Then do your job, Tim.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: What is my job, Mr. Smith? Maybe I'd better find out before Macreedy does it for me.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Macreedy'll do nothing, Tim. And neither will you.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Suppose I decide to try?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: That would be dangerous. You got the body of a hippo, Tim, but the brain of a rabbit. Don't overtax it.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Yes, Mr. Smith.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: From L.A.?

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: Yeah! From that private detective!

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: What does he say? Who is this guy?

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: Never heard of him, that's what he says! He checked and there's no John J. Macreedy. No listing -- no record -- no information. Nothing.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Where does that leave us?

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: I'll tell you where...

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Shut up!

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Now, Coley...?

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: I think Macreedy's a nothing. A nobody.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Is he?

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: So there's nothing to worry about.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Isn't there?  You got brains, you have.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: Suppose he finds out?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: A nobody like Macreedy can raise a pretty big stink. The point is... who would miss a nobody like Macreedy if he just, say, disappeared? Who, Coley?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Coley!

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Why don't we wait...

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Wait for what?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: I mean, maybe he won't find anything. Maybe he'll just go away.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Not Macreedy. I know those maimed guys. Their minds get twisted. They put on hair shirts and act like martyrs. They're all of 'em do- gooders, trouble makers, freaks.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: But there's no danger yet. Let's wait and see.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: ...your own sister -- acts like a fool.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: She's just a kid.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: And he says what's the danger.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Of course, if you want to take the chance...

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: Not me.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: All right, then...

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: It's not all right! You're so mighty quick to kill -- he's not an animal!

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You sniveling toad! I'm saving your neck! If I don't, who will?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: All I said...

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Who will?! Doc? Tim? Your sister, with the rocks in her head?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: One thing about your sister -- she's got twice the guts you have. You're only fit for running away.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: It's too late for that.  He's in this, and he ain't running no place.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: All right, then...

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Let Smith find himself a new boy. I can't take it another day.  They just laugh.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I don't laugh, Tim.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Why don't you?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Cut it out, Tim.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: You should!

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: In the name of well-adjusted manhood, snap out of it. You're going to get a complex or something.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Four years ago if I'd of done my job... if I'd of checked up and found out what happened. But I didn't! Just like Smith figured.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: What could you have found out? They told you a story. You had to believe it.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Do you believe it?

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Do you know what happened?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I don't know.  I lead a quiet, contemplative life.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Me, I didn't even try to find out.  Me... I did nothin'. And that's what's eatin' me. What kind of prescription you got for that?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I don't know. I've never been able to find one for myself.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Only one thing -- don't quit, Tim.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Maybe this feller Macreedy has the prescription.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: Well, if it's not Macreedy - the world's champion road hog.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Yeah. It's a small world.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: But such an unfriendly one. Now why did you want to crowd me off the road?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I'm kind of sorry if I've incurred your displeasure.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: Look what you did to my car.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: If there's anything I can do to make up for it...

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: You ought to be careful, man -- all that one-arm driving.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I'd be glad to pay the damages.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: It's a threat to life and limb.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Fortunately no one was hurt.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: You could get yourself killed that way -- nosin' all over the countryside.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: That's the real danger, I can see that.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: Why that's pretty smart of you. How long you intend to keep it up?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I'm getting out of here, right now.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Still expecting that convention?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: What...?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: If you're expecting any extra cowboys, my room is available.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: You're checking out?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Is there a train through here tonight?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Nothing till tomorrow morning. The streamliner.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I know that. How about freights?  Milk train?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Tomorrow. After the streamliner.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Busses?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Closest stop is Sand City -- thirty- two miles away.  You're in such a hurry, you should have never got off here.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I'm inclined to agree with you.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Anybody home?

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: If you're looking for the jeep key...

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: ...it's not there...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: In that case, where do you suggest I look?

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: The jeep's not for rent.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: It was, just a few hours ago.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Things change.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Sure. And Smith is the kid who changes 'em.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Miss Brooks.  What's the matter with this town of yours?

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Nothing. It's none of your concern.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Then why are they all so concerned about me?

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Am I concerned?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: No, you're not. But...

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: But what?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: But it strikes me you're a little too unconcerned. So unconcerned you won't even rent me a jeep.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: I don't run a taxi service. I don't have a license.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I wish others in this town were as scrupulously devoted to law and order as you are.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Why don't you lay off! If you don't like it here, go back where you came from!

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Funny thing. They try to kill me, and you feel persecuted.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: I don't want to get involved.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Involved in what?

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Whatever you're up to. Whatever happens, I've got to go on living here. These people are my neighbors, my friends.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: All of them?

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: This is my town, Mr. Macreedy, like it or not. Whatever happened here, it was long ago, now it's... it's...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Whatever did happen, you don't seem to like it. Why do you stick around?

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Because of my brother. Pete. He'd never leave.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Didn't you ever think of going without him. You're sort of independent and he's... he's...

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Weak. I know. That's why I couldn't leave him.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: What did your brother do?

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: He... I...  What do you care? What do you care about Black Rock?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Nothing much. Only, there're not many places like this in America -- but even one is too many. Because I think something sort of bad happened here.  Something I can't find the handle to...

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: You just think so. You don't know.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: This much I know -- the rule of law has been suspended in this town. The gorillas have taken over.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: You're a fine one to talk! You come in here, sneaking around, trying to steal the key to my jeep.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I kind of had a notion that was the only way I could get it.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Was I wrong, Miss Brooks?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I'd like to ask you a few questions... as long as you're around...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I'm around all right.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: You probably know that Miss Brooks is no longer in the car rental business?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Good. I wouldn't want to see that girl get into trouble...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: You wouldn't?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: ...what with rental permits, gas rationing... you know what I mean.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Sure. I admire your sturdy sense of responsibility.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: It's just, a girl like that has a future.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Let's talk about my future.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Do you have the time?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I don't seem to be going any place.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I hear you handle a jeep real well.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I have a way with jeeps. A certain familiarity.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I think I understand. You're an Army man.  Where'd you get it?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Italy.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Tough. I tried to get in myself, the day after those rats bombed Pearl Harbor.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: What stopped you?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: The physical. They wouldn't take me. The morning after Pearl, I was the first man in line at Marine recruiting in Sand City. And they wouldn't take me.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Tough.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: What do you do in Los Angeles, Mr. Macreedy?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I'm retired.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You're a pretty young man...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: You might say I was forced into retirement.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: What were you looking for in Adobe Flat?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Komako, like I told you. Like you told me, he wasn't there.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: What's so funny?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Nothing. It's just -- I don't believe you. I believe a man is as big as what he seeks. I believe you're a big man, Mr. Macreedy.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Flattery will get you nowhere.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Why would a man like you be looking for a lousy Jap farmer?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Maybe I'm not so big.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Yes, you are.  I believe that a man is as big as the things that make him mad. Nobody around here has been big enough to make you mad.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: What makes you mad, Mr. Smith?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Me...? Nothing in particular.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: ...the Japanese make you mad...

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: That's different. After the sneak attack on Pearl Harbor... after Bataan...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: ...and Komako made you mad.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: It's the same thing.  Loyal Japanese-Americans -- that's a laugh. They're mad dogs. Look at Corregidor, the death march.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: What did Komako have to do with Corregidor?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Wasn't he a Jap? Look, Macreedy, there's a law in this county against shooting dogs. But if I see a mad dog loose, I don't wait for him to bite me.  I swear, you're beginning to make me mad.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: All strangers do.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Not all. Some of 'em. When they come here snooping.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Snooping for what?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I mean, outsiders coming around, looking for something.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: For what?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I don't know. People are always looking for something in this part of the West. To the historian, it's the "Old West." To the book writers, it's the "Wild West." To the businessmen, it's the "Undeveloped West." They all say we're backward and poor, and I guess we are.  I just wish they'd leave us alone.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Leave you alone to do what?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I don't know what you mean.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: What happened to Komako?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: He went away, I told you. Shortly after he left, a bunch of kids got fooling around out his place. They burned it down. It was one of those things -- you know how kids are.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: What's funny?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Nothing. Only -- I don't believe you. Any more than I believed you about the letters.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You don't seem to believe anything I say.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Yes, I do -- about businessmen, for instance. I think a businessman would be interested in Adobe Flat.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: All that land lying fallow. Could be put to some use. Like a graveyard.  A historian might be interested, too. Because of the strange customs around here, such as burying cattle...

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Burying cattle...?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Something's buried out there.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: See these wild flowers? That means a grave. I've seen it overseas. I figure it isn't a man's grave or someone would have marked it. Sort of a mystery, isn't it?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Sort of. Maybe you can figure it out.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Maybe.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Why not give it a whirl?  ...for a while.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Not interested. I got other things to do.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Hi. Pull up a chair.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Can I use your phone?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Help yourself.  You know, you're one of the few people who's ever been back here I can say that to.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: What's 4-2-4?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: If I've got you pegged -- and I think I have -- you're calling the State Police. But if I was you -- and I'm purely glad I'm not -- I'd look it up myself.  I wouldn't trust anybody around here, including me.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I know -- don't tell me -- lines all busy. They'll be busy all day.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Don't look at me like that.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Like what?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Like I'm a potential customer.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Everybody is -- and I get 'em coming and going.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: First I sell 'em a piece of land. Think they farm it? Nope. They dig for gold.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: They rip off the top soil of ten winding hills. They sprint in here, fog-heaved with excitement, lugging nuggets, big and bright and shiny.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Is it gold?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: It is not! Do they quit? They do not!

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Then they decide to farm. Farm! In country so dry you have to prime a man before he can spit, and before you can say "Fat Sam" they're stalled, stranded and starving. They get weevil- brained and buttsprung...

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: But why should I bore you with my triumphs?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Yeah. I've got a problem of my own.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: They're going to kill you with no hard feelings.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: And you'll just sit on your hands and let them.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Don't get waspish with me, young feller.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I feel for you, but I'm consumed with apathy. Why should I mix in?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: To save a life.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I got enough trouble saving my own.  I try to live right and drink my orange juice every day. But mostly I try to mind my own business. Which is something I'd advise you to do.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: It's a little late for that...

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: You can still get out of town. And you'd better get out like a whisper.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: How can I?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I got sort of a limousine at your disposal.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Where is it?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Out back.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Won't start.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Something wrong?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Just won't start...

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: Could be the wirin'. Why don't you look under the hood?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: For that I thank you.  How much time you think I've got before...?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: They'll wait at least till dark.  They'd be afraid to see each other's faces.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Well, so long, Doc. I can't say it's been charming but...

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Where are you going?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I don't know. But I'm going on foot.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: That's no good. You stray ten yards off Main Street, and you'll be stone, cold dead.  That's the situation, in a nut.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: It's the wirin', like I said. Now wasn't that a good guess?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: It can be fixed.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: Easy. Unless, of course, this here wire...  ...got broke or something.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Do the nice little things, like keep your big fat nose out of my business.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: Yep. It's the wirin'.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I'm sorry, son. You got to admit, I tried.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Maybe...

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Maybe what?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: If I can't get out of town, maybe I can get the state cops in.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: You tried the phone, didn't you? You know what happened, don't you?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: There's another way. I'll be seeing you, Doc.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I hope you'll be seeing me.

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: You notifyin' the state po-lice?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: That's what it says.

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: Lemonade?

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: It's hot as Billy-be-durned.

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: Don't you like lemonade?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I never thought much about it.

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: It don't have the muzzle velocity of some other drinks drunk around here, but it's good for what ails you.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: What ails you, Mr. Hastings?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Why are you so upset about...  ...this wire?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Are you afraid, Mr. Hastings?

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: Me...?  You don't know what it's like, being scared.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: You want me to describe the symptoms? Right this minute I'm scared half to death.

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: You should be.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Yeah. But not of the state police.

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: Neither am I.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Then what are you afraid of? The grave at Adobe Flat? A grave nobody marked, nobody knows anything about.

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: That ain't it, either.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Is it Smith?  Is it?!

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: Look, Mr. Macreedy. I'm just a good neighbor...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: To Smith you are. How about to Komako?

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: I never seen Komako in my life. Honest.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Then send that wire, and bring me the answer. You'll do that, won't you?

Speaker: hastings
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: krool
Dialogue: I tell you, I won't have anything to do with it.

Speaker: murtry
Dialogue: Live and let live, that's what I say.

Speaker: bentham
Dialogue: I don't know. I just don't know.

Speaker: lenard
Dialogue: You gonna brood about it? Or you want another beer?

Speaker: bentham
Dialogue: A beer, I guess. Only...

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What'll you have?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: What have you got?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Chili wit' beans.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Anything else?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Chili wit'out beans.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You don't like the taste, that's what they make ketchup for.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: In that case, I'll have it. And a cup of coffee.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: You still around? I thought you didn't like this place.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Going to, or coming from?

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: Staying put.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: No comment.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: No comment, he says. No comment, and all the time he's got my chair.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I always seem to be taking somebody's place around here.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: This seat ain't comfortable.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I was afraid of that.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: I think I'd like the seat you're on.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: He's as changeable as a prairie fire.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Suppose you tell me where to sit.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: I hope that ain't too much.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Your friend's a very [...] fellow.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Sort of unpredictable, too. Got a temper like a rattlesnake.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: That's me all over. I'm half hoss, half alligator. Mess with me, I'll kick a lung outta you. What do you think of that?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: No comment.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: Talking to you is like pulling teeth. You wear me out.  You're a yellow-bellied Jap lover. Am I right or wrong?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: You're not only wrong -- you're wrong at the top of your voice.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: You don't like my voice?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I think your friend's trying to start something.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Now why-ever would he want to do that?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I don't know. Maybe he figures, needle me enough and I'll crack. Maybe I'll even fight back. Then he or Hector -- your other ape -- would beat me to death and cop a plea of self-defense.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I don't think that'll be necessary. You're so scared now you'll probably drown in your own sweat.

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: Before that happens, couldn't I pick a fight with you if I tied one hand behind me...?

Speaker: coley
Dialogue: If I tied both hands...?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Or are there too many witnesses present?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You're still in trouble.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: So are you.  Whatever happens -- you're lost.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You got things a bit twisted...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: You killed Komako. Sooner or later you'll go up for it. Not because you killed him -- in this town you probably could have gotten away with it -- but because you didn't even have the guts to do it alone. You put your trust in guys like him...  ...and Hector -- they're not the most dependable of God's creatures. Sooner or later they'll get the idea you're playing them for saps. What'll you do then -- peel them off, one by one? And in the meantime if any one of them breaks, you'll go down hard. Because they got something on you. Something to use when things get tough.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: And they're getting tougher every minute.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Man... man-oh-man.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Anything for me?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Any message -- a telegram?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I'm truly sorry to say.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: Your friend's pretty tough.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Yeah. He's wicked. He defends himself when he's attacked.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Well...? You going to just sit here and let time run out?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I'm waiting for a wire. From the state cops.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: You sent it through Hastings?  Just don't expect an answer, if that's the way you sent it.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Where's the answer?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You expect an answer -- to a wire that's never sent?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: What's so funny?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Nothing. Just a thought --  -- a thought dazzling in its purity...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: You're in a jam, Hastings. You gave my telegram to Smith.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: You warty wretch! That's a federal offense!

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Sheriff, you'd better do something about this.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: I reckon that's right, Mr. Smith...

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: Don't be a jerk, Tim.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Divulging information -- there's a law...

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Tim, you're pathetic.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Could be. But I'm still Sheriff.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: That's the point. You're not Sheriff any more. You just lost a job, you're so pathetic.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: All right, Sheriff. Take over.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: You can't do that!

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Can't I? I put him in office. Now I take him out.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: Now. You want to register a complaint?

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: To register a complaint, boy, you've got to have evidence. You got evidence?

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: You got a big mouth, boy, makin' accusations, disturbin' the peace. There's laws in this county protectin' innocent folks from big mouths. Why, I'd just hate to...

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Come on, Hector.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: It's all right, Tim. We're not licked yet.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Ain't we? I am.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: There comes a time, Tim, when a man's just got to do something.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Not me. I'm useless, and I know it.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: No man is useless, if he's got a friend...

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I'm your friend, Tim.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Then let me alone.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: He's going to need you before the night is over.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: And all the useful men are on the other side.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Lemme alone, I tell ya!

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I can't let you alone! I can't let myself alone! Don't you understand that?  Four years ago something terrible happened here. We did nothing about it. Nothing. The whole town fell into a sort of settled melancholy, and the people in it closed their eyes and held their tongues and failed the test with a whimper.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Now something terrible is going to happen again, and in a way we're lucky because we've been given a second chance. And this time I won't close my eyes, I won't hold my tongue, and if I'm needed I won't fail.  And neither will you!

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: I got such a headache, I'm bewildered. I hurt all over.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I know --  Funny, how a man clings to the earth when he feels there's a chance he may never see it again.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: There's a difference between clinging to the earth...  ...and crawling on it. You going to stand by and watch forever?

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: I ain't gonna watch, and I ain't gonna get into it, either.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: I'm gettin' out. I'm sorry, Mr. Macreedy.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: You'd be smart to get out, too.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: There's too many smart guys around here. I'm glad I'm a dummy.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: You're a troublesome dummy. You're liable to end up on your own slab...

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I expect to be in a lot more trouble before I die...

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Go home, Doc.  He's all washed up.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: You think so?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I was washed up when I got off that train...

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: You shouldn' of got off.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Had to. I had one last duty to perform before I resigned from the human race.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I thought you were going to Los Angeles, that hot-bed of pomp and vanity. Is that resigning from the human race?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: L.A.'s a good jumping off place -- for the Islands, for Mexico, Central America.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I don't know. I was looking for a place to get lost, I guess.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Thanks to your friend Smith, I found I was wrong.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Sure. You're a man of action.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: ...or silently, without making you feel too uncomfortable... or thankfully, without making your memories of the occasion too unpleasant.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: My memories are so pleasant as it is...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: What happened, Pete?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Are you going to tell him -- or you want me to?  Smith owns Adobe Flat. He leased it to Komako -- thought he had cheated him, thought Komako could never even run stock without water. There was never any water on Adobe Flat. Komako dug a well, by hand. He must have went down one hundred and fifty feet.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: He got water, plenty. Smith was pretty sore. He didn't like Japs anyway.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: That's an understatement.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: The day after Pearl Harbor, Smith went to Sand City.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I know. To enlist. He was turned down.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: He was sore when he got back. About ten o'clock he started drinking.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Ten o'clock in the morning.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Yeah. Hector joined him, and Coley. Then Sam, and about nine p.m. -- me. We were all drunk -- patriotic drunk. We went out to Komako's for a little fun, I guess -- scare him a little.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Did you know him?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: We'd seen him around some, but none of us knew him. When he heard us coming, he locked the door. Smith started a fire. The Jap came running out. His clothes were burning. Smith shot him. I didn't even know Smith had a gun.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Then you all got scared, buried him, kept quiet.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Did Komako have any family besides his son Joe?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: His son...? Nobody around here knew he had a son.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: He had one. But he's dead, too. He's buried in Italy.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: What are you doing here, Mr. Macreedy?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Joe Komako died in Italy, saving my life. They gave him a medal. I came here to give it to his father.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: God forgive me...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: It'll take a lot of whiskey to wash out your guts...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: ...And it will never help -- not even a barrel full washes away murder!

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: But maybe I'm wrong. Go on -- drink.  You also don't know that it's not enough to feel guilty. It's not enough to confess. It's not enough to say, "Forgive me, I've done wrong."

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Take it easy, Macreedy. Sit down.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Sit down?! Or would you rather have me kneel, to beg his pardon for raising a touchy subject?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: You don't have to remind me. I've never forgotten...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Well, that's mighty noble of you. You feel ashamed -- that's noble, too.  And four years from now you'll probably be sitting here telling somebody else you haven't forgotten me. That's progress -- you'll still be ashamed but I'll be dead.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Go on, have your drink.  You need it.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Hello, Liz. Now listen... I... 'm getting Macreedy out of town...

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: I don't care about Smith! Let him try to kill me -- I might as well be dead as...

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: All right. Yeah... I've told him everything.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: She'll be here in five minutes.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Thanks, Pete. Thanks very much.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Hector!

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: Hmmmm?

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: What you want?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: He's still in his room. Macreedy, I mean.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: So...? You want me to tuck him in?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: I thought maybe you wanted to tell Smith.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: Smith said he'd be here at midnight. He don't want to be disturbed.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: You got a match?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Come on. I got some in the lobby.

Speaker: hector
Dialogue: I thought you didn't have a match.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: ...for depriving me of that pleasure.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Sorry I can't get more out of this heap.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: We could make better time with a dog team.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Aren't you, Liz?

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Don't expect too much from me.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Don't worry, I won't.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: I mean, people have always expected things from me. You know why? Because I'm pretty. Well, that's not enough.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: You don't believe that.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Yes I do.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Well, I don't, really. I'm a dime a dozen.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: That I don't believe.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: I'm too little and too late.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: It's never too late.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: I lack the muscle.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Why is muscle so important?

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Did it take brains to rough up Coley? Whatever you did to Hector, you didn't do it with brains. How'd you get Pete to change his mind?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Not with muscle.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: And not with brains, either. He's a pushover for a muscle man.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I'm beginning' to think it runs in the family.  You think strength is in the width of a man's shoulders.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: I'd sure have liked to see you tangle with Reno Smith.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: He wasn't around when I left... Maybe I will yet.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: What's this?

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: ...radiator's overheating.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Leggo! Leggo of me!

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: You're stupid, Liz. You're a fool. If he finishes me, he's got to finish you.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Smitty! Smitty!

Speaker: smith's voice
Dialogue: I'm here, honey. Just head for the car.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: So long, Macreedy.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Just a few more steps, honey.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Get him! Get him now!

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: First things first, honey.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Help me up, Smitty.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You were going to help me, Liz.  I still need your help.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: I did what you said...

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You two started out in a car. That's the way you'll end up. Over a cliff, burning.  You can blame that on Macreedy, too. He said I had too many witnesses.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: But why me? Why start with me?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I got to start with somebody.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Macreedy! Macreedy!

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: You shouldn't have done that...

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Go ahead -- kill me. Now.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: I'd like to kill you now, but you caused too much pain to die quickly.  You'll be tried in a court of law. You'll be convicted by a jury. Then you'll die.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Hands behind your head.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Am I going to have trouble with you?

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Nope. But I sure thought the situation was going to be like reversed. I thought I was going to have trouble...  ...with him. I'll take care of him.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Just as you took care of his buddies?

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: Just as I took care of his buddies. Me, an' Doc, and Pete...

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: It's all right, Macreedy...

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Old Tim here's got his badge back.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Well. The gang is all here.

Speaker: tim
Dialogue: I thought I'd take one last whack at my job. Even if Smith killed me for it.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Put him in with Hastings.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Your sister's outside, Pete.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: She's dead.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Tim knows where to find me if I'm needed.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: What's on your mind, Doc?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Nothing. Only... about that medal. Can we have it?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: "We...?" Can who have it?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: We.  Us.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Well, we need it, I guess. It's something we can maybe build on. This town is wrecked, just as bad as if it was bombed out. Maybe it can come back...

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Some towns come back. Some don't. It depends on the people.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: That medal would help.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Thanks, Macreedy. Thanks for everything.

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: What's the excitement? What happened?

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: A shooting.

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: I knew it was something. First time a streamliner stopped here in four years.

Speaker: macreedy
Dialogue: Second time.
